metadata.title: Metal-Organic Framework Derived Co9S8 Embedded in N, O and S- Tridoped Carbon Nanomaterials as Efficient Oxygen Bifunctional Electrocatalyst

DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
Metal-Organic Framework Derived Co9S8 Embedded in N, O and STridoped Carbon Nanomaterials as Efficient Oxygen Bifunctional Electrocatalyst
Jin-Yan Zhao,‡ Rui Wang,‡ Shan Wang, Ya-Ru Lv, Hong Xu, Shuang-Quan Zang*
Designing tailor-made metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) to
synthesize target nanomaterials with extraordinary
electrochemical oxygen catalytic activity is highly desirable. Here,
we rationally designed a 2D Co-MOF [Co(BDC)2(SPDP)2(DMF)(H2O)], (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, SPDP = 4,4'-(sulfonylbis(4,1phenylene))dipyridine, DMF = N, N-dimethylformamide) as single-
source precursor through direct carbonization to afford the N, O
and S-tridoped carbon matrix encapsulated with Co9S8 nanocomposites (Co9S8@TDC). By virtue of the intrinsic activity of Co9S8 nanoparticles (NPs) as well as the heteroatom doped carbon shell, Co9S8@TDC possess attractive oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalytic
activities in alkaline solution. Specially, Co9S8@TDC-900 displayed an overpotential of 330 mV (vs. RHE) at current density of 10 mA cm-2 for OER and half-wave potential of 0.78 V (vs. RHE) for ORR with limiting current density of 5.45 mA cm-2, rivalling the
performance of RuO2 and Pt/C. As the proof of concept, Co9S8@TDC-900 was employed as a bifunctional oxygen catalyst for rechargeable Zn-air battery, exhibiting a considerable open-circuit
voltage (1.50 V) and impressive long-term charge/discharge stability (45 h at 5 mA cm-2). The straightforward strategy provides
a facile method for further exploration of non-noble metal
electrochemical oxygen reaction catalysts.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Bifunctional electrocatalyst of oxygen reduction reaction
(ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is vitally important
for various sustainable energy devices, such as fuel cell and metal-air batteries.1-2 So far, both the well-known ORR/OER
electrocatalysts of Pt/C and RuO2 cannot be employed as
bifunctional electrocatalysts. Moreover, the scarcity and
sluggish reaction kinetic as well as the high cost hinder the wide
use of Pt/C and RuO2. Great efforts have been devoted to developing efficient, stable and low-cost bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts.3,4 Among them, earth abundant transition
metal (e.g. Fe, Co and Ni) based oxides, sulfides, phosphides
have been extensively study because of their high catalytic activity and natural abundance.5-7
Recently, Co9S8 has been demonstrate catalytic activity towards OER,8-10 but was unsatisfactory for the ORR activity.11,12
Also, the poor electrical conductivity, small specific surface
area, easy aggregation of NPs and limited intrinsic activities
impeded its practicable application. To improve the
electrocatalytic performance of Co9S8, heteroatom-doped (e.g., N,13 O,14 P15 and S16) carbon nanocomposite has been
introduced into the system as a protective shell to wrap Co9S8 NPs and effectively promote the catalytic performance
synergistically, which is due to the electronic and structural
modulation of doped-heteroatoms on the carbon matrix. For
example, Dai et al. reported a N-doped porous carbon support
Co9S8 nanomaterial, displaying high ORR and OER electrocatalytic activity.6 However, in most cases of
construction for heteroatoms doped carbon encapsulating
Co9S8 hybrid materials, tedious synthesis procedures and additional substrates were required.14,17,18 Therefore, looking
for new raw materials to facilely synthesize the heteroatom-
doped carbon material encapsulating Co9S8 NPs nanocomposites for OER and ORR is necessary.
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) featuring the high
surface area, tuneable metal ions and organic linkers, are a
promising template to obtain the hybrid oxygen electrocatalysts with high performance.19-23 However, the preparation of MOF-
derived heteroatom-doped, even multiple-doped carbon
nanocomposite materials was usually limited in the use of some typical MOF-precursors, such as ZIF-67,24 ZIF-8,25 MIL-101.26
And the additional compound containing required heteroatom
was also needed to be introduced before calcination, or the College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China. *E-mail: zangsqzg@zzu.edu.cn DOI:10.1039/x0xx00000x ‡ These authors contributed equally to this work

sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
further treatment (sulfidation) was needed for the synthetization of metal sulphide.27 Thus, designing
Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the synthesis process of Co9S8@TDC as bifunctional electrocatalysts.
tailor-made MOFs to synthesize target nanomaterials with
extraordinary electrochemical oxygen catalytic properties are
highly desirable, yet remains a challenge.
Herein, we elaborately designed and synthesized a novel Co-
MOF constructed by SPDP and H2BDC ligands. The resulted CoMOF was simply carbonized to formed Co9S8 NPs embedded in N, O, and S-tridoped carbon hybrid nanomaterials
(Co9S8@TDC). The porous structures, Co9S8 NPs and heteroatoms doped carbon shell synergistically promoted the
catalytic performance of Co9S8@TDC for OER and ORR, which both showed the excellent catalytic activity and long-term
stability. Specially, Co9S8@TDC-900 displayed an overpotential of 330 mV (vs. RHE) at current density of 10 mA cm-2 for OER
and half-wave potential of 0.78 V (vs. RHE) for ORR with limiting current density of 5.45 mA cm-2. Furthermore, we assembled
the Zn-air battery by using Co9S8@TDC-900 as air-cathode catalyst, which exhibited excellent performance and long-term
stability.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
The as-prepared Co-MOF crystallizes in the triclinic space
group P-1 (Table S1). In the asymmetric unit of Co-MOF, the Co
(II) nodes were connected by two linkers, i.e., N, S, O-atom-
containing SPDP and auxiliary H2BDC ligand, forming a 2D nested structure. Each bridging SPDP and H2BDC ligand was completely deprotonated, binding to Co (II) ions through N
atom and O atom, respectively. Three-dimensional
supramolecular structure was formed by the dislocated stacking
of 2D layers (Fig. S1a-c). The experimental details could be
found in the supporting information. The powder X-ray
diffraction (PXRD) and elemental analysis of the as-synthesized
Co-MOF was shown in Fig. S1d and Table S2, which indicated
the high crystallinity and purity of Co-MOF.
Fig. 1 and supporting information of experiment clearly
illuminate the preparation strategy of Co9S8@TDC composite. The synthesized Co-MOF was calcined in a tubular furnace of
600 °C, 700 °C, 800 °C and 900 °C, respectively. The hybrid
materials calcined at different temperature were characterized
by PXRD (Fig. S2) and washed in 1.0 M hydrochloric acid which
could etch off some unstable Co9S8 and Co particles (Fig. S3). The final obtained materials were denoted as Co9S8@TDC-600, 700, 800 and 900. The PXRD diffraction peaks of all final samples
showed good agreement with cubic-phase Co9S8 (JCPDS NO. 86- 2273) (Fig. 2a).28 Diffraction signals at 15.4°, 29.8°, 31.2°, 47.5°
and 52.1° were assigned to the (111), (311), (222), (511) and
(440) facets of Co9S8 phase. The specific surface area and porous features of the samples were determined by N2 adsorptiondesorption measurement (Fig. 2b and Fig. S4). The isotherms of
Co9S8@TDC all exhibited type-I and type-IV isotherm characteristics, with a steep increase at low pressure and the
slight hysteretic trait of the desorption isotherm at high
pressure, suggesting the existence of different pore size spanning from micropores to macropores.5 The Brunaure-

sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Fig. 2 Characterization of Co9S8@TDC. a) Powder XRD patterns; b) N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K; c) Raman spectra; d) SEM image of Co9S8@TDC-900; e) TEM image and f) HR-TEM image of Co9S8@TDC-900; g) Elemental mapping images of Co9S8@TDC-900 showing the uniform presence of C, N, O, S, and Co.
Emmett- Teller (BET) surface area of Co9S8@TDC-900 was up to 247.2 m2 g-1, which is much larger than other three pre-
synthesized samples (Table S3). The pore size distribution
calculation by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT)
model revealed the micropores, mesopores and macropores
structure of all samples. The hierarchical pore structure was
helpful for bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalysts. Macropores
serving as the gas transport channel, and abundant mesopores
as reaction regions for the gas-liquid-solid tri-phase ORR and OER reactions.29 Overall, the large surface area together with
hierarchically porous features could offer abundant accessible
active sites and mass-transfer pathway for OER and ORR,
benefitting for the catalytic activity. In the Raman spectrum (Fig. 2c), two strong peaks were shown at 1345 cm-1 and 1590 cm-1 corresponding to the defect/disordered sp3 hybrid carbon (D band) and crystalline graphitic sp2 carbon (G band).30 The
intensity ratio (ID/IG) was usually used to evaluate the level of graphitic ordering. The ID/IG of the samples varied from 0.96 to 1.03, indicating that the increase of pyrolytic temperature
resulted higher degree of defects in the materials. Larger
defects were helpful for enhancing the catalytic in OER and ORR.31 Meanwhile, two distinguished peaks at 460.4 cm-1 and 665.3 cm-1 could be assigned to the characteristic peak of Co9S8.32 The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Co9S8@TDC materials indicated the porous morphology, which was beneficial for the mass transfer of oxygen between
electrolyte and catalyst surface (Fig. 2d and Fig. S5). The
detailed morphology of the Co9S8@TDC-900 nanocomposites was investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
and high resolution TEM (HRTEM). Fig. 2e showed that spherical
Co9S8 NPs were uniform in both size and shape, also well encapsulated in the modified carbon with the size less than 10
nm. The HRTEM image of Co9S8@TDC-900 was shown in Fig. 2f, it was observed that the d-spacing value (lattice fringe) was 0.28
nm which was assigned to the (222) plane of Co9S8. Elemental mapping results indicated that the region was rich with C, N, O
and S elements and seldom with Co elements (Fig. 2g). These
results were in accordance with the presence of Co9S8 crystals that was encapsulated in heteroatom-doped carbon matrix.
The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried
out to investigate the surface compositions and chemical states
of Co9S8@TDC. As shown in Fig. 3a, the survey XPS spectrums of Co9S8@TDC clearly showed the presence of C, N, O, S and Co, demonstrating the N, O and S were successfully doped into the carbon.14 The high-resolution scan of the C 1s electrons yielded
four peaks, the dominant peak at 284.6 eV corresponding to
C=C–C carbon species, and the relatively small peaks at 285.7
eV and 286.4 eV were assigned to C–S and C–N/C–O. The low
intensity broad band at 288.4 eV was assigned to C=O (Fig. 3b).33,34 For the N 1s spectrum, the asymmetric N 1s peak could
be fitted into three peaks at binding energy of 398.0 eV, 399.7
eV and 401.7 eV corresponded to the pyridine-N, pyrrolic-N and graphitic-N, respectively (Fig. 3c).35,36 Commonly, pyridinic-N
was regarded as the active component to enhance the electron-
donating capability; it was believed that pyridinic-N facilitates
ORR, in particular by improving the onset potential.
Additionally,

Fig. 3 a) XPS spectra of Co9S8@TDC; b)-f) High resolution XPS spectra of C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, S 2p and Co 2p for Co9S8@TDC-900.
graphitic-N was believed to increase the limiting current density.37,38 Fig. 3d showed that the O 1s spectrum had two
separated peaks at 531.4 eV and 532.3 eV for C=O and C–O– C/SOxn-, respectively.39,40 The high-resolution XPS S 2p peaks revealed the presence of Co–S (163.7 eV), C–S–C (164.8 eV), C=S (165.0 eV) and SOxn- (168.5 eV) (Fig. 3e).41,42 The Co–S peak was originated from the Co9S8. In addition, the appearance of the SOxn- could be ascribed to the partial oxidation of S. In the highresolution Co 2p spectrum, the core level of the Co 2p spectrum
was deconvoluted into two spin-orbit doublets and two
shakeup satellites (identified as “Sat.”). The peaks at 781.0 eV
and 797.3 eV were consistent with Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively (Fig. 3f), and the doublets were assigned to Co2+ (781.0 eV, 797.1 eV) and Co3+ (778.5 eV, 794.6 eV).10,43 The
above results verified that the hybrid materials consisting of the
Co9S8 NPs were embedded in N, O and S-tridoped carbon networks.

sections.heading: 3. Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
Motivated by the highly desirable characteristics of Co9S8TDC, electrochemical measurements were carried out to study
their performance of oxygen reaction catalysis. The OER activity
was first tested through linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurement with the scan rate of 5 mV s-1 (Fig. 4a).
Commercial RuO2 and bare glassy carbon electrode (GCE) (Fig. 4a) were carried out for comparison under the identical
conditions. Among the as-prepared samples, Co9S8@TDC-900
exhibited the smaller overpotential (330 mV) than Co9S8@TDC600 (548 mV), Co9S8@TDC-700 (429 mV) and Co9S8@TDC-800 (391 mV) to afford the current density of 10 mA cm−2,
demonstrating the relatively high OER activity of Co9S8@TDC900. Also, at the same current density, the overpotential
needed for OER was much smaller than other three samples
under the same conditions (Fig. S6). In Fig. 4b, the Tafel curves
(η=b log j + a, where η is overpotential, b is the Tafel slope, j is the current density and a is a constant)44 estimated the OER
kinetics of Co9S8@TDC and RuO2. The Tafel slope for Co9S8@TDC-900 was calculated to be 86 mV dec-1, which was lower than other three samples and a little higher than RuO2. The results reflected good intrinsic OER kinetics and faster
oxygen evolution on Co9S8@TDC-900 catalyst. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was great
significance accounting for the high intrinsic OER activity, which reflected the effective number of electrocatalytic active sites.45
The ECSA of the electrocatalyst was known to be proportional
to the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), which could be evaluated by measuring scan-rate dependent cyclic
voltammetry (CV) in the non-faradaic region (Fig. S7). The measured Cdl value of Co9S8@TDC-900 was 27.57 mF cm-2, which was larger than other three samples (Fig. S8). The larger
Cdl manifested more exposing surface reactive sites and much higher current density of Co9S8@TDC-900. To further illustrate the electrode reaction kinetics during the catalytic OER process,
the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was
performed. In Fig. S9, the Nyquist plots revealed the

sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 5
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Fig. 4 Electrochemical and electrocatalytic properties of Co9S8@TDC nanomaterials, RuO2 and Pt/C. a) LSV curves of various samples for OER in 1.0 M KOH; b) the corresponding Tafel curves; c) CV curves of Co9S8@TDC-900 in O2- and N2- saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1; d) LSV curves of various samples for ORR in 0.1 M KOH; e) ORR polarization curves of Co9S8@TDC-900 at different rotating speeds; f) K–L plots of Co9S8@TDC-900 at different potentials.
Co9S8@TDC-900 had a lower charge transfer resistance (Rct) about 54.1 Ω at the electrocatalyst-electrolyte interface, sugge-
sting the faster electron transfer process during the
electrochemical reaction. The great charge transport ability was
mainly endowed by N, O and S-tridoped carbon and Co9S8 NPs evenly embedded in the carbon shell. In addition, we performed
chronoamperometric i-t measurement of Co9S8@TDC-900 at a constant potential of 1.58 V (vs. RHE). After 7 h, the current
density was retained with the 95.5% of initial (Fig. S10). These
results firmly demonstrated the excellent activity and stability
of Co9S8@TDC-900 for OER.
The ORR catalytic activities of Co9S8@TDC samples were also investigated. CV measurements were first performed in O2or N2-saturated 0.1 M aqueous KOH solution in a conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell. As shown in Fig. 4c,
Co9S8@TDC-900 showed a distinct oxygen reduction peak (≈0.75 V vs. RHE) in O2-saturated electrolyte but no obvious peak in N2-saturated electrolyte, indicating the intrinsic ORR activity of Co9S8@TDC-900 catalyst.46 The polarization curves of the Co9S8@TDC catalysts were demonstrated in Fig. 4d, and the half-wave potential of Co9S8@TDC-900 reached 0.78 V (vs. RHE), which was similar with that Pt/C,47 together with a limiting current density of 5.45 mA cm−2 at 1600 rpm. Compared with
the other three samples, Co9S8@TDC-900 has more positive ORR half-wave potential and largest cathodic current density,
suggesting its superior activity for ORR. The better ORR activity
of Co9S8@TDC-900 compared with other three as-prepared
samples should be attributed to the synergetic effect of large
specific surface area and heteroatoms-doped carbon.
Furthermore, the ORR kinetics and reaction path of catalyst
were investigated by the LSV measurement at different rotation
speeds ranging from 400 to 2500 rpm. As shown in Fig. 4e, Fig.
S11a-S12a and Fig. S14a, the limiting current density of the
Co9S8@TDC-700, 800, 900 and Pt/C increases with the raise of the rotational speed, which resulted from an increase in the
diffusion rate of O2 on the electrode surface. The linear Koutecky–Levich (K–L) plots obtained from the corresponding
LSV plots at different rotation rates indicated first-order
reaction kinetics with regard to the concentration of dissolved
oxygen and similar electron transfer numbers (n) at various potential.48,49 The value of n was calculated to be 3.94‐4.07 for
Co9S8@TDC-900 (Fig. 4f), 3.94‐4.03 for Co9S8@TDC-800 (Fig. S12b), 3.90‐3.94 for Co9S8@TDC-700 (Fig. S11b) and 3.96-3.98 for Pt/C (Fig. S14b) at different potentials, indicating the
Co9S8@TDC catalysts followed a four-electron-transfer process for the reduction of oxygen to water. Additionally, we
performed the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) test to monitor the formation of H2O2 during the ORR process.15 As shown in Fig. S11-S14, the measured yields of H2O2 generated at the disk electrode vary over the potential range 0.2 V-0.7 V
was lower than 22% for Co9S8@TDC-700, 800 and Pt/C. The H2O2 yields of Co9S8@TDC-900 was less than 8%. In addition, there was no change in the half-wave potential with the attenuation of only 0.2 mA cm-2 for the limiting current density

sections.text:
6 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Fig. 5 a) Open-circuit plots of a single battery of the Zn-air battery using Co9S8@TDC-900 as the air-cathode (Left: photograph of the assembled battery with an open-circuit voltage of 1.50 V. Right: red LED powered by two-series batteries); b) Polarization curves and the corresponding power density curves; c) Long-term cycling tests at the charging and discharging current density of 5 mA cm-2 (10 min for each cycle).
after 3000 cycles measurement (Fig. S14a). The result of
methanol tolerance experiment (Fig. S13b) revealed the
Co9S8@TDC-900 was more stable than Pt/C in alkaline conditions for methanol resistance. Consequently, we
concluded that the Co9S8@TDC-900 exhibited similar catalytic activity with Pt/C but had superior stability than Pt/C, thus
Co9S8@TDC-900 would likely be practical in energy conversion equipment application. To further revealed the structural
benefits of the interpenetrating interfaces in Co9S8@TDC, the OER and ORR of synthetic pure Co9S8 material (P-Co9S8) were measured (Fig. S15). As expected, the P-Co9S8 had larger overpotential (370 mV) at 10 mA cm-2 for OER, the corresponding tafel slope of 91 mV dec-1 was also higher than
Co9S8@TDC-900 (Fig. S16a), which may be due to its high impedance and the lower ECSA in electrolyte confirmed by the tiny Cdl (0.09 mF cm-1) and the small specific surface area (8.92 m2 g-1) (Fig. S16-S17). In addition, no obvious reduction peak
was observed in CV curves for ORR (Fig. S18). The results of
above experiments indicated that the remarkable bifunctional
electrocatalytic performance for OER and ORR of Co9S8@TDC were attributed to the unique structural advantage of active
Co9S8 NPs encapsulated by the multi-heteroatom doped carbon material.
By comparing the potential gap (∆E ) between Ej=10 of OER and Ehalf-wave of ORR (∆E= Ej=10-Ehalf-wave) (Fig. S19), Co9S8@TDC-900 exhibited smaller ∆E about 0.78 V among the as-prepared
catalysts, indicating its bifunctional catalytic ability. The OER
and ORR catalytic properties of Co9S8@TDC-900 were close to RuO2 and Pt/C, and significantly were better than most nonnoble metal catalysts under the same test conditions (Table S4).
Given that the charge process of Zn-air batteries was driven by
OER kinetics, while the discharge process was catalyzed by ORR
on the air-cathode side, we further explored the bifunctional
applicability of Co9S8@TDC-900 as cathodes of Zn-air batteries. As shown in Fig. 5a and Fig. 5b, the primary Zn-air battery
exhibited an open-circuit potential (OCP) as high as 1.50 V and a peak power density of 101.5 mW cm-2. The OCP was tested in
the static ambient atmosphere without external gas purging
and the battery remained stable for 35 h. Furthermore, two
primary Zn-air batteries connected in series could power a red
light-emitting diode (LED). Additionally, the efficiency and long-
term rechargeability of Co9S8@TDC-900 for Zn-air batteries were evaluated by galvanostatic charge/discharge at 5 mA cm2. The initial charge/discharge potentials of the primary Zn‐air
battery were 2.03 V and 0.93 V with a voltage gap of 1.10 V in a
short interval (10 min per cycle) of charging and discharging. As
shown in Fig. 5c, the discharge voltage was enhanced slightly
(almost negligible) after 20 h cycling, which maintained the
initial charge potential of 2.03 V and increased the discharge
potential to 1.01 V, corresponding to a decrease in
charge/discharge voltage gap by 0.08 V and no obvious
potential drop after long-term charging and discharging
process, demonstrating its excellent activity and stability,
similar to other reported state-of-the-art electrode materials
(Table S5).

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, our study demonstrated a facile and effective
method to obtain the Co9S8 embedded in N, O and S-tridoped carbon composites (Co9S8@TDC) through one-step carbonization of a 2D Co-MOF, which constructed by 4,4'-
(sulfonylbis(4,1-phenylene))dipyridine and 1,4-
benzenedicarboxylic acid. Taking advantages of the
homogeneously distributed Co9S8 NPs and abundant N-, O-, Sheteroatoms doped active sites in the porous carbon network,
the resultant Co9S8@TDC displayed excellent bifunctional ORR and OER electrocatalytic activity and long-term stability.
Furthermore, the Co9S8@TDC-900 was applied in the Zn-air battery with outstanding performance and stability. This
strategy may pave the way for designing more tailor-made
MOFs as templates to achieve novel metallic hybrid materials
for the application of energy conversion.
